heading: Events
txt: Empress Wu Zetian establishes the Zhou Dynasty of China.

entities.title: Wu Zetian
entities.description: Wu Zhao, commonly known as Wu Zetian, alternatively Wu Hou, and during the later Tang dynasty as Tian Hou, was the de facto ruler of China, first through her husband the Emperor Gaozong (唐高宗) and then through her sons the Emperors Zhongzong (唐中宗) and Ruizong (唐睿宗), from 665 to 690. She subsequently became empress regnant of the Zhou dynasty (周) of China, ruling from 690 to 705. She is notable for

entities.title: Zhou dynasty (690–705)
entities.description: The Wu Zhou, known officially as Zhou, also called the Southern Zhou dynasty, Second Zhou dynasty or Restored Zhou dynasty, was a Chinese dynasty that existed between 690 and 705 AD, when Wu Zetian ruled as Empress Regnant. The dynasty began when Wu Zhao, which was Wu Zetian's personal name, usurped the throne of her son, the Emperor Ruizong of Tang, and lasted until Emperor Zhongzong of Tang was

heading: Events
txt: London tornado of 1091: A tornado thought to be of strength T8/F4 strikes the heart of London.

entities.title: London tornado of 1091
entities.description: The London Tornado of 1091 is reckoned by modern assessment of the reports as possibly a T8 tornado which occurred in London in the Kingdom of England and was the earliest reported tornado in that area, occurring on Friday, 17 October 1091. The wooden London Bridge was demolished, and the church of St. Mary-le-Bow in the city of London was badly damaged; four rafters 26 feet (7.9 m) long were driv

heading: Events
txt: The English capture King David II of Scotland at Neville's Cross and imprison him for eleven years.

entities.title: David II of Scotland
entities.description: David II was King of Scotland for nearly 42 years, from 1329 until his death in 1371. He was the last male of the House of Bruce. Although David spent long periods in exile or captivity, he managed to ensure the survival of his kingdom and left the Scottish monarchy in a strong position.

entities.title: Battle of Neville's Cross
entities.description: The Battle of Neville's Cross took place during the Second War of Scottish Independence on 17 October 1346, half a mile to the west of Durham, England. An invading Scottish army of 12,000 led by King David II was defeated with heavy loss by an English army of approximately 6,000–7,000 men led by Ralph Neville, Lord Neville. The battle was named after an Anglo-Saxon stone cross that stood on the hi

heading: Events
txt: An Ottoman army defeats a Hungarian army at the Second Battle of Kosovo.

entities.title: Battle of Kosovo (1448)
entities.description: The Second Battle of Kosovo was a land battle between a Hungarian-led Crusader army and the Ottoman Empire at Kosovo Polje. It was the culmination of a Hungarian offensive to avenge the defeat at Varna four years earlier.

heading: Events
txt: The University of Greifswald is established as the second oldest university in northern Europe.

entities.title: University of Greifswald
entities.description: The University of Greifswald, formerly also known as “Ernst-Moritz-Arnt University of Greifswald“, is a public research university located in Greifswald, Germany, in the state of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern.

heading: Events
txt: Anti-Catholic posters appear in Paris and other cities supporting Huldrych Zwingli's position on the Mass.

entities.title: Affair of the Placards
entities.description: The Affair of the Placards was an incident in which anti-Catholic posters appeared in public places in Paris and in four major provincial cities, Blois, Rouen, Tours and Orléans, in the night of the 17th to the 18th of October, 1534. One of the posters was posted on the bedchamber door of King Francis I at Amboise, an affront and a breach of security that left him shaken. The Affaire des Placards

heading: Events
txt: Poczta Polska, the Polish postal service, is founded.

entities.title: Poczta Polska
entities.description: Poczta Polska is the state postal administration of Poland, initially founded in 1558. It is the largest mail-handling company in the country, which additionally provides courier, banking, insurance and logistics services. The digital services, such as neo-stamps, neo-letters and neo-postcards, are available through the Internet-based platform 'Envelo'.

heading: Events
txt: Kepler's Supernova is observed in the constellation of Ophiuchus.

entities.title: Kepler's Supernova
entities.description: SN 1604, also known as Kepler's Supernova, Kepler's Nova or Kepler's Star, was a Type Ia supernova that occurred in the Milky Way, in the constellation Ophiuchus. Appearing in 1604, it is the most recent supernova in our galaxy to have been unquestionably observed by the naked eye, occurring no farther than 6 kiloparsecs from Earth. Prior to the adoption of the current naming system for supernovae

heading: Events
txt: French king Louis XIII is crowned in Reims Cathedral.

entities.title: Louis XIII of France
entities.description: Louis XIII was King of France from 1610 to 1643 and King of Navarre from 1610 to 1620, when the crown of Navarre was merged with the French crown.

heading: Events
txt: The nine regicides who signed the death warrant of Charles I of England are hanged, drawn and quartered.

entities.title: List of regicides of Charles I
entities.description: Following the trial of Charles I in January 1649, 59 commissioners (judges) signed his death warrant. They, along with several key associates and numerous court officials, were the subject of punishment following the restoration of the monarchy in 1660 with the coronation of Charles II. Charles I's trial and execution had followed the second English Civil War in which his supporters, Royalist "Cav

entities.title: Charles I of England
entities.description: Charles I was King of England, Scotland, and Ireland from 27 March 1625 until his execution in 1649. He was born into the House of Stuart as the second son of King James VI of Scotland, but after his father inherited the English throne in 1603, he moved to England, where he spent much of the rest of his life. He became heir apparent to the three kingdoms of England, Scotland, and Ireland in 1612 o

heading: Events
txt: Charles II of England sells Dunkirk to Louis XIV of France for 40,000 pounds.

entities.title: Sale of Dunkirk
entities.description: The Sale of Dunkirk took place on 27 October [O.S. 17 October] 1662 when Charles II of England sold his sovereign rights to Dunkirk and Fort-Mardyck to his cousin Louis XIV of France.

heading: Events
txt: Premiere in Milan of the opera Ascanio in Alba, composed by Mozart at age 15.

heading: Events
txt: American Revolutionary War: British General John Burgoyne surrenders his army at Saratoga, New York.

entities.title: Saratoga campaign
entities.description: The Saratoga campaign in 1777 was an attempt by the British high command for North America to gain military control of the strategically important Hudson River valley during the American Revolutionary War. It ended in the surrender of the British army, which historian Edmund Morgan argues, "was a great turning point of the war, because it won for Americans the foreign assistance which was the last

heading: Events
txt: American Revolutionary War: British General Charles, Earl Cornwallis surrenders at the Siege of Yorktown.

entities.title: Siege of Yorktown
entities.description: The siege of Yorktown, also known as the Battle of Yorktown, the surrender at Yorktown, or the German battle, ending on October 19, 1781, at Yorktown, Virginia, was a decisive victory by a combined force of the American Continental Army troops led by General George Washington and Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette, and French Army troops led by Comte de Rochambeau over a British army commande

heading: Events
txt: War of the Second Coalition: Britain takes control of the Dutch colony of Curaçao.

entities.title: Invasion of Curaçao (1800)
entities.description: The Invasion of Curaçao in 1800 during the War of the Second Coalition was launched by French forces against the Batavian Republic. The French had landed on the island on 22 July, and on 5 September attacked and captured a fort protecting the town of Willemstad, Curaçao. The American consul sent for help, and on 10 September the Dutch governor of the island surrendered to a British frigate, HMS Ne

heading: Events
txt: Former leader of the Haitian Revolution, Emperor Jacques I, is assassinated after an oppressive rule.

entities.title: Jean-Jacques Dessalines
entities.description: Jean-Jacques Dessalines was a leader of the Haitian Revolution and the first ruler of an independent Haiti under the 1805 constitution. Under Dessalines, Haiti became the first country to permanently abolish slavery. Initially regarded as governor-general, Dessalines was later named Emperor of Haiti as Jacques I (1804–1806) by generals of the Haitian Revolution Army and ruled in that capacity unti

heading: Events
txt: Eight people die in the London Beer Flood.

entities.title: London Beer Flood
entities.description: The London Beer Flood was an accident at Meux & Co's Horse Shoe Brewery, London, on 17 October 1814. It took place when one of the 22-foot-tall (6.7 m) wooden vats of fermenting porter burst. The pressure of the escaping liquid dislodged the valve of another vessel and destroyed several large barrels: between 128,000 and 323,000 imperial gallons of beer were released in total.

heading: Events
txt: The tomb of Pharaoh Seti I is discovered.

entities.title: KV17
entities.description: Tomb KV17, located in Egypt's Valley of the Kings and also known by the names "Belzoni's tomb", "the Tomb of Apis", and "the Tomb of Psammis, son of Nechois", is the tomb of Pharaoh Seti I of the Nineteenth Dynasty. It is one of the best decorated tombs in the valley, but now is almost always closed to the public due to damage. As per November 2017 holders of a 1200 EGP entry ticket or of a Luxor

heading: Events
txt: First The Open Championship (referred to in North America as the British Open).

entities.title: The Open Championship
entities.description: The Open Championship, often referred to as The Open or the British Open, is the oldest golf tournament in the world, and one of the most prestigious. Founded in 1860, it was originally held annually at Prestwick Golf Club, Scotland, before evolving to being rotated between a select group of coastal links golf courses in the United Kingdom, under the authority of The R&A.

heading: Events
txt: Aboriginal Australians kill nineteen Europeans in the Cullin-la-ringo massacre.

entities.title: Cullin-la-ringo massacre
entities.description: The Cullin-la-ringo massacre, known historically as the Wills tragedy, occurred north of modern-day Springsure in Central Queensland on 17 October 1861. It remains the largest massacre of white settlers by Aboriginals in Australian history, and a pivotal moment in the frontier wars in Queensland.

heading: Events
txt: Marconi begins the first commercial transatlantic wireless service.

entities.title: Marconi Company
entities.description: The Marconi Company was a British telecommunications and engineering company that did business under that name from 1963 to 1987. It was derived from earlier variations in the name and incorporation, spanning a period from its inception in 1897 until 2006, during which time it underwent numerous changes, mergers and acquisitions. The company was founded by the Italian inventor Guglielmo Marconi an

heading: Events
txt: Bulgaria, Greece and Serbia declare war on the Ottoman Empire, joining Montenegro in the First Balkan War.

entities.title: First Balkan War
entities.description: The First Balkan War lasted from October 1912 to May 1913 and involved actions of the Balkan League against the Ottoman Empire. The Balkan states' combined armies overcame the initially numerically inferior and strategically disadvantaged Ottoman armies and achieved rapid success.

heading: Events
txt: Al Capone is convicted of income tax evasion.

entities.title: Al Capone
entities.description: Alphonse Gabriel Capone, sometimes known by the nickname "Scarface", was an American gangster and businessman who attained notoriety during the Prohibition era as the co-founder and boss of the Chicago Outfit. His seven-year reign as a crime boss ended when he went to prison at the age of 33.

heading: Events
txt: Albert Einstein flees Nazi Germany and moves to the United States.

entities.title: Albert Einstein
entities.description: Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest physicists of all time. Einstein is known for developing the theory of relativity, but he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics. Relativity and quantum mechanics are together the two pillars of modern physics. His mass–energy equivalence formula E

heading: Events
txt: The body of Communist propagandist Willi Münzenberg found in South France, starting a never-resolved mystery.

entities.title: Willi Münzenberg
entities.description: Wilhelm "Willi" Münzenberg was a German Communist political activist and publisher. Münzenberg was the first head of the Young Communist International in 1919–20 and established the famine-relief and propaganda organization Workers International Relief in 1921. He was a leading propagandist for the Communist Party of Germany (KPD) during the Weimar Era, but later grew disenchanted with the USSR du

heading: Events
txt: World War II: The USS Kearny becomes the first U.S. Navy vessel to be torpedoed by a U-boat.

entities.title: USS Kearny (DD-432)
entities.description: USS Kearny (DD-432), a Gleaves-class destroyer, was a United States Navy warship during World War II. She was noted for being torpedoed by a German U-boat in October 1941, before the U.S. had entered the war. She survived that attack, and later served in North Africa and the Mediterranean.

heading: Events
txt: The Burma Railway (Burma–Thailand Railway) is completed.

entities.title: Burma Railway
entities.description: The Burma Railway, also known as the Death Railway, the Siam–Burma Railway, the Thai–Burma Railway and similar names, is a 415 km (258 mi) railway between Ban Pong, Thailand and Thanbyuzayat, Burma, built by the Empire of Japan from 1940–1944 to supply troops and weapons in the Burma campaign of World War II. This railway completed the rail link between Bangkok, Thailand and Rangoon, Burma. The na

heading: Events
txt: Nazi Holocaust in Poland: Sobibór extermination camp is closed.

heading: Events
txt: A massive demonstration in Buenos Aires, Argentina, demands Juan Perón's release.

entities.title: Loyalty Day (Argentina)
entities.description: Loyalty Day is a commemoration day in Argentina. It remembers October 17, 1945, when a massive labour demonstration at Plaza de Mayo demanded the liberation of Juan Domingo Perón, who was jailed in Martín García island. It is considered the foundation day of Peronism.

heading: Events
txt: The first commercial nuclear power station is officially opened by Queen Elizabeth II in Sellafield, England.

entities.title: Sellafield
entities.description: Sellafield is a large multi-function nuclear site close to Seascale on the coast of Cumbria, England. As of August 2020, activities at the site include nuclear fuel reprocessing, nuclear waste storage and nuclear decommissioning, and it is a former nuclear power generating site. The licensed site covers an area of 265 hectares and comprises more than 200 nuclear facilities and more than 1,000 buil

heading: Events
txt: Directed by their chief Maurice Papon, Paris police massacre scores of Algerian protesters.

entities.title: Paris massacre of 1961
entities.description: The Paris massacre of 1961 occurred on 17 October 1961, during the Algerian War (1954–62). Under orders from the head of the Parisian police, Maurice Papon, the French National Police attacked a demonstration by 30,000 pro-National Liberation Front (FLN) Algerians. After 37 years of denial and censorship of the press, in 1998 the French government finally acknowledged 40 deaths, although there are

heading: Events
txt: The 1964–65 New York World's Fair closes after two years and more than 51 million attendees.

entities.title: 1964 New York World's Fair
entities.description: The 1964/1965 New York World's Fair was a world's fair that held over 140 pavilions, 110 restaurants, for 80 nations, 24 US states, and over 45 corporations to build exhibits or attractions at Flushing Meadows–Corona Park in Queens, New York City. The immense fair covered 646 acres (2.61 km2) on half the park, with numerous pools or fountains, and an amusement park with rides near the lake. Howeve

heading: Events
txt: The 23rd Street Fire in New York City kills 12 firefighters.

entities.title: 23rd Street Fire
entities.description: The 23rd Street Fire was an incident that took place in the Flatiron District neighborhood of Manhattan, New York City, on October 17, 1966. A group of firefighters from the New York City Fire Department responding to a fire at 7 East 22nd Street entered a building at 6 East 23rd Street as part of an effort to fight the fire. Twelve firefighters were killed after the floor collapsed, the largest l

heading: Events
txt: The Caravaggio painting Nativity with St. Francis and St. Lawrence is stolen from the Oratory of Saint Lawrence in Palermo.

entities.title: Caravaggio
entities.description: Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio was an Italian painter active in Rome for most of his artistic life. During the final four years of his life he moved between Naples, Malta, and Sicily until his death. His paintings combine a realistic observation of the human state, both physical and emotional, with a dramatic use of lighting, which had a formative influence on Baroque painting.

entities.title: Oratory of Saint Lawrence
entities.description: The Oratory of Saint Lawrence is a Baroque oratory of Palermo. It is located near the Basilica of Saint Francis of Assisi, in the quarter of the Kalsa, within the historic centre of Palermo.

entities.title: Palermo
entities.description: Palermo is a city in southern Italy, the capital of both the autonomous region of Sicily and the Metropolitan City of Palermo, the city's surrounding metropolitan province. The city is noted for its history, culture, architecture and gastronomy, playing an important role throughout much of its existence; it is over 2,700 years old. Palermo is in the northwest of the island of Sicily, by the Gulf o

heading: Events
txt: FLQ terrorists murder Quebec Vice-Premier and Minister of Labour Pierre Laporte.

entities.title: October Crisis
entities.description: The October Crisis refers to a chain of events that started in October 1970 when members of the Front de libération du Québec (FLQ) kidnapped the provincial Deputy Premier Pierre Laporte and British diplomat James Cross from his Montreal residence. These events saw the Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau invoking the War Measures Act for the first time in Canadian history during peacetime.

heading: Events
txt: OPEC imposes an oil embargo against countries they deem to have helped Israel in the Yom Kippur War.

entities.title: 1973 oil crisis
entities.description: The 1973 oil crisis began in October 1973 when the members of the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries proclaimed an oil embargo. The embargo was targeted at nations perceived as supporting Israel during the Yom Kippur War. The initial nations targeted were Canada, Japan, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and the United States with the embargo also later extended to Portugal, Rhode

heading: Events
txt: The hijacked Lufthansa Flight 181 lands in Mogadishu. The remaining hostages are later rescued.

entities.title: Lufthansa Flight 181
entities.description: Lufthansa Flight 181 was a Boeing 737-230C jetliner named the Landshut that was hijacked on the afternoon of 13 October 1977 by four members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, who called themselves Commando Martyr Halima. The objective of the hijacking was to secure the release of imprisoned Red Army Faction leaders in German prisons. In the early hours of 18 October, just after

heading: Events
txt: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.

entities.title: Mother Teresa
entities.description: Mother Mary Teresa Bojaxhiu, honoured in the Catholic Church as Saint Teresa of Calcutta, was an Albanian-Indian Roman Catholic nun and missionary. She was born in Skopje, then part of the Kosovo Vilayet of the Ottoman Empire. After living in Skopje for eighteen years, she moved to Ireland and then to India, where she lived for most of her life.

heading: Events
txt: The Department of Education Organization Act creates the U.S. Department of Education.

heading: Events
txt: As part of the Holy See–United Kingdom relations a British monarch makes the first state visit to the Vatican.

entities.title: Holy See–United Kingdom relations
entities.description: Holy See–United Kingdom relations are foreign relations between the Holy See and the United Kingdom.

heading: Events
txt: Uganda Airlines Flight 775 crashes at Rome–Fiumicino International Airport, in Rome, Italy, killing 33 people.

entities.title: Uganda Airlines Flight 775
entities.description: Uganda Airlines Flight 775 was a Boeing 707-338C, registration 5X-UBC, that crashed while attempting to land at Rome-Fiumicino Airport in Rome, Italy on 17 October 1988. Thirty-three of the 52 occupants on board were killed.

entities.title: Leonardo da Vinci–Fiumicino Airport
entities.description: Rome–Fiumicino International Airport "Leonardo da Vinci" is an international airport in Rome and the major airport in Italy. It is one of the busiest airports in Europe by passenger traffic with over 43.5 million passengers served in 2019.

entities.title: Rome
entities.description: Rome is the capital city and a special comune of Italy, as well as the capital of the Lazio region. The city has been a major human settlement for almost three millennia. With 2,860,009 residents in 1,285 km2 (496.1 sq mi), it is also the country's most populated comune. It is the third most populous city in the European Union by population within city limits. It is the centre of the Metropolitan

entities.title: Italy
entities.description: Italy, officially the Italian Republic, is a country consisting of a continental part, delimited by the Alps, a peninsula and several islands surrounding it. Italy is located in Southern Europe, and is also considered part of Western Europe. A unitary parliamentary republic with Rome as its capital, the country covers a total area of 301,340 km2 (116,350 sq mi) and shares land borders with France,

heading: Events
txt: The 6.9 Mw Loma Prieta earthquake shakes the San Francisco Bay Area and the Central Coast, killing 63.

entities.title: Seismic magnitude scales
entities.description: Seismic magnitude scales are used to describe the overall strength or "size" of an earthquake. These are distinguished from seismic intensity scales that categorize the intensity or severity of ground shaking (quaking) caused by an earthquake at a given location. Magnitudes are usually determined from measurements of an earthquake's seismic waves as recorded on a seismogram. Magnitude scales vary

entities.title: 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake
entities.description: The 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake occurred on California's Central Coast on October 17 at 5:04 p.m. local time. The shock was centered in The Forest of Nisene Marks State Park in Santa Cruz County, approximately 10 mi (16 km) northeast of Santa Cruz on a section of the San Andreas Fault System and was named for the nearby Loma Prieta Peak in the Santa Cruz Mountains. With an Mw magnitude of 6.9 and

heading: Events
txt: The East German Politburo votes to remove Erich Honecker from his role as General Secretary.

heading: Events
txt: 1991 Rudrapur bombings by Sikh separatists, who explode two bombs, during a Ramlila Hindu celebration in Rudrapur, Uttarakhand, killing 41 people.

entities.title: 1991 Rudrapur bombings
entities.description: 1991 Rudrapur bombings were bombings by the suspected terrorists in 1991 in Rudrapur city in Indian state of Uttarakhand. Two bombs were exploded on 17 October 1991. The first bomb exploded when people were watching Ramlila in the public ground. After 15 minutes the second bomb went off near the hospital where injured were being taken. The bombings killed more than 40 people and injuring 140 peopl

entities.title: Ramlila
entities.description: Ramlila (Rāmlīlā) is any dramatic folk re-enactment of the life of Rama according to the ancient Hindu epic Ramayana or secondary literature based on it such as the Ramcharitmanas. It particularly refers to the thousands of Hindu god Rama-related dramatic plays and dance events, that are staged during the annual autumn festival of Navratri in India. After the enactment of the legendary war between

entities.title: Hindu
entities.description: Hindus are persons who regard themselves as culturally, ethnically, or religiously adhering to aspects of Hinduism. Historically, the term has also been used as a geographical, cultural, and later religious identifier for people living in the Indian subcontinent.

entities.title: Rudrapur, Uttarakhand
entities.description: Rudrapur is a city in Udham Singh Nagar district in the Indian state of Uttarakhand. Located at a distance of about 250 km (160 mi) northeast of New Delhi and 250 km (160 mi) south of Dehradun, Rudrapur has a history of over 500 years. It was established in the 16th century by King Rudra Chand, and was the residence of the governor of Tarai region of Kumaon. The city continues to serve as the head

heading: Events
txt: Having gone to the wrong house, Japanese student Yoshihiro Hattori is killed by the homeowner in Baton Rouge, Louisiana.

entities.title: Death of Yoshihiro Hattori
entities.description: Yoshihiro Hattori  was a Japanese student on an exchange program to the United States who was shot to death in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. He was on his way to a Halloween party and went to the wrong house by mistake. Property owner Rodney Peairs fatally shot Hattori, thinking that he was trespassing with criminal intent. The shooting and Peairs' acquittal in the state court of Louisiana received worl

heading: Events
txt: Russian journalist Dmitry Kholodov is assassinated while investigating corruption in the armed forces.

entities.title: Dmitry Kholodov
entities.description: Dmitry Yuryevich Kholodov was a Russian journalist who investigated corruption in the military and was assassinated on 17 October 1994 in Moscow. His assassination was the first of many killings of journalists in Russia.

heading: Events
txt: The Hatfield rail crash leads to the collapse of Railtrack.

entities.title: Hatfield rail crash
entities.description: The Hatfield rail crash was a railway accident on 17 October 2000, at Hatfield, Hertfordshire. It was caused by a metal fatigue-induced derailment, killing four people and injuring more than 70.

heading: Events
txt: Israeli tourism minister Rehavam Ze'evi becomes the first Israeli minister to be assassinated in a terrorist attack.

entities.title: Assassination of Rehavam Ze'evi
entities.description: Israel's tourism minister Rehavam Ze'evi was assassinated shortly before 7 am (GMT+2) on Wednesday, 17 October 2001 at the former Hyatt Hotel in Jerusalem by a squad of Palestinians acting on behalf of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine militant organization. Ze'evi was the first Israeli minister to be assassinated since the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin and the most senior Israeli

heading: Events
txt: Taipei 101, a 101-floor skyscraper in Taipei, becomes the world's tallest high-rise.

entities.title: Taipei 101
entities.description: The Taipei 101, formerly known as the Taipei World Financial Center (臺北國際金融中心), is an extremely tall skyscraper designed by C.Y. Lee and C.P. Wang in Xinyi, Taipei, Taiwan. This building was officially classified as the world's tallest from its opening in 2004 until the 2009 completion of the Burj Khalifa in Dubai, UAE.

heading: Events
txt: The recreational use of cannabis is legalized in Canada.

entities.title: Cannabis Act
entities.description: The Cannabis Act is a law which legalized recreational cannabis use nationwide in Canada in combination with its companion legislation Bill C-46, An Act to Amend the Criminal Code. The law is a milestone in the legal history of cannabis in Canada, alongside the 1923 prohibition.

heading: Events
txt: Kerch Polytechnic College attack in Crimea.

heading: Events
txt: Drug dealers in Culiacan, Sinaloa, Mexico force the government to back down on an arrest.

entities.title: Culiacan
entities.description: Culiacán, officially Culiacán Rosales, is a city in northwestern Mexico that is the capital of and the largest city in Sinaloa and in the Culiacán Municipality. It was founded on September 29, 1531 by the Spanish conquerors Lázaro de Cebreros and Nuño Beltrán de Guzmán under the name of Villa de San Miguel, which referred to its patron saint, Michael the Archangel.

entities.title: Battle of Culiacán
entities.description: The Battle of Culiacán was a failed operation by the Mexican National Guard to capture Ovidio Guzmán López, who is wanted in the United States for drug trafficking.

heading: Births
txt: Lý Nam Đế, first emperor of Vietnam (d. 548)

entities.title: Lý Nam Đế
entities.description: Lý Nam Đế was a Vietnamese monarch and the founder of Vạn Xuân. ruling between 544-8 and the founder of the Early Lý Dynasty.

entities.title: History of Vietnam
entities.description: The history of Vietnam can be traced back to around 20,000 years ago. Archaeological findings from 1965, still under research, show the remains of two hominins closely related to Sinanthropus, dating as far back as the Middle Pleistocene era, roughly half a million years ago. Pre-historic Vietnam was home to some of the world's earliest civilizations and societies—making them one of the world's fi

heading: Births
txt: Ivo of Kermartin, French priest and saint (d. 1303)

entities.title: Ivo of Kermartin
entities.description: Ivo of Kermartin, T.O.S.F., also known Yvo, Yves, or Ives, was a parish priest among the poor of Louannec, the only one of his station to be canonized in the Middle Ages. He is the patron of Brittany, lawyers and abandoned children. His feast day is 19 May. Poetically, he is referred to as "Advocate of the Poor".

heading: Births
txt: Bartolommeo Bandinelli, Italian sculptor (d. 1560)

entities.title: Bartolommeo Bandinelli
entities.description: Bartolommeo Bandinelli, actually Bartolommeo Brandini, was a Renaissance Italian sculptor, draughtsman and painter.

heading: Births
txt: Alonso de Orozco Mena, Spanish Roman Catholic priest (d. 1591)

entities.title: Alonso de Orozco Mena
entities.description: Alonso de Orozco Mena was a Spanish Roman Catholic priest from the Augustinian order. He was well known across Spain for his preaching abilities and for an austere and humble life.

heading: Births
txt: Irene di Spilimbergo, Italian Renaissance poet and painter (d. 1559)

entities.title: Irene di Spilimbergo
entities.description: Irene di Spilimbergo was an Italian Renaissance painter and poet.

heading: Births
txt: Cristofano Allori, Italian painter (d. 1621)

entities.title: Cristofano Allori
entities.description: Cristofano Allori was an Italian painter of the late Florentine Mannerist school, painting mostly portraits and religious subjects. Allori was born at Florence and received his first lessons in painting from his father, Alessandro Allori, but becoming dissatisfied with the hard anatomical drawing and cold coloring of the latter, he entered the studio of Gregorio Pagani, who was one of the leaders

heading: Births
txt: Dmitry Pozharsky, Russian prince (d. 1642)

heading: Births
txt: Johann Gerhard, German theologian and academic (d. 1637)

entities.title: Johann Gerhard
entities.description: Johannes Gerhard was a Lutheran church leader and Lutheran Scholastic theologian during the period of Orthodoxy.

heading: Births
txt: Nathan Field, English dramatist and actor (d. 1620)

entities.title: Nathan Field
entities.description: Nathan Field was an English dramatist. He was also an actor.

heading: Births
txt: Francis Turretin, Swiss-Italian minister, theologian, and academic (d. 1687)

entities.title: Francis Turretin
entities.description: François Turrettini was a Genevan-Italian Reformed scholastic theologian.

heading: Births
txt: Balthasar Charles, Prince of Asturias (d. 1646)

entities.title: Balthasar Charles, Prince of Asturias
entities.description: Balthasar Charles, Prince of Asturias, Prince of Girona, Duke of Montblanc, Count of Cervera, and Lord of Balaguer, Prince of Viana was heir apparent to all the kingdoms, states and dominions of the Spanish monarchy until his death.

heading: Births
txt: Domenico Zipoli, Italian missionary and composer (d. 1726)

entities.title: Domenico Zipoli
entities.description: Domenico Zipoli was an Italian Baroque composer who worked and died in Córdoba, in the Viceroyalty of Peru, Spanish Empire,. He became a Jesuit in order to work in the Reductions of Paraguay where he taught music among the Guaraní people. He is remembered as the most accomplished musician among Jesuit missionaries.

heading: Births
txt: Jupiter Hammon, American poet (d. 1806)

entities.title: Jupiter Hammon
entities.description: Jupiter Hammon is known as a founder of African-American literature, as his poem published in 1761 in New York was the first by an African American in North America. He published both poetry and prose after that. In addition, he was a preacher and a commercial clerk on Long Island, New York.

heading: Births
txt: Jacques Cazotte, French author and academic (d. 1792)

entities.title: Jacques Cazotte
entities.description: Jacques Cazotte was a French author.

heading: Births
txt: Maria Teresa Agnesi Pinottini, Italian harpsichord player and composer (d. 1795)

entities.title: Maria Teresa Agnesi Pinottini
entities.description: Maria Teresa Agnesi was an Italian composer. Though she was most famous for her compositions, she was also an accomplished harpsichordist and singer, and the majority of her surviving compositions were written for keyboard, the voice, or both.

entities.title: Harpsichord
entities.description: A harpsichord is a musical instrument played by means of a keyboard. This activates a row of levers that turn a trigger mechanism that plucks one or more strings with a small plectrum made from quill or plastic. The strings are under tension on a soundboard, which is mounted in a wooden case; the soundboard amplifies the vibrations from the strings so that the listeners can hear it. Like a pipe or

heading: Births
txt: John Wilkes, English journalist and politician (d. 1797)

entities.title: John Wilkes
entities.description: John Wilkes was a British radical journalist and politician, as well as a magistrate, essayist and soldier. He was first elected a Member of Parliament in 1757. In the Middlesex election dispute, he fought for the right of his voters—rather than the House of Commons—to determine their representatives. In 1768, angry protests of his supporters were suppressed in the St George's Fields Massacre. In

heading: Births
txt: Pierre-Alexandre Monsigny, French composer and academic (d. 1817)

entities.title: Pierre-Alexandre Monsigny
entities.description: Pierre-Alexandre Monsigny was a French composer and a member of the French Académie des Beaux-Arts (1813).

heading: Births
txt: Franz Xaver Feuchtmayer the Younger, German Baroque artist (d. 1803)

entities.title: Franz Xaver Feuchtmayer the Younger
entities.description: Franz Xaver Feuchtmayer  was a member of the German Feuchtmayer family of Baroque artists associated with the Wessobrunner School.

entities.title: Baroque
entities.description: The Baroque is a style of architecture, music, dance, painting, sculpture and other arts that flourished in Europe from the early 17th century until the 1740s. In the territories of the Spanish and Portuguese empires including the Iberian Peninsula it continued, together with new styles, until the first decade of the 1800s. It followed Renaissance art and Mannerism and preceded the Rococo and Neoc

heading: Births
txt: Andrey Voronikhin, Russian architect and painter (d. 1814)

entities.title: Andrey Voronikhin
entities.description: Andrey (Andrei) Nikiforovich Voronikhin was a Russian architect and painter. As a representative of classicism he was also one of the founders of the monumental Russian Empire style. Born a serf of the Stroganov family, he is best known for his work on Kazan Cathedral in Saint Petersburg.

heading: Births
txt: Claude Henri de Rouvroy, comte de Saint-Simon, French economist and philosopher (d. 1825)

entities.title: Claude Henri de Rouvroy, comte de Saint-Simon
entities.description: Claude Henri de Rouvroy, comte de Saint-Simon, often referred to as Henri de Saint-Simon, was a French political, economic and socialist theorist and businessman whose thought had a substantial influence on politics, economics, sociology and the philosophy of science.

heading: Births
txt: Sophie von Dönhoff, morganatic spouse by bigamy to King Frederick William II of Prussia (d. 1838)

entities.title: Sophie von Dönhoff
entities.description: Countess Sophie Friederike Juliane von Dönhoff was a German lady-in-waiting and a morganatic spouse by bigamy to King Frederick William II of Prussia.

entities.title: Morganatic
entities.description: Morganatic marriage, sometimes called a left-handed marriage, is a marriage between people of unequal social rank, which in the context of royalty or other inherited title prevents the principal's position or privileges being passed to the spouse, or any children born of the marriage.

heading: Births
txt: Louis Charles, French prince of the blood (d. 1808)

entities.title: Louis Charles, Count of Beaujolais
entities.description: Louis Charles Alphonse Léodgard d'Orléans, Count of Beaujolais was a French prince of the blood, son of Philippe Égalité and the younger brother of King Louis-Philippe I of the French.

entities.title: Prince of the blood
entities.description: A prince du sang is a person legitimately descended in male line from a sovereign, the female equivalent of princess of the blood being applied to the daughter of a prince of the blood. The most prominent examples include members of the French royal line, but the term prince of the blood has been used in other families more generally, for example among the British royal family and when referring t

heading: Births
txt: José Andrés Pacheco de Melo, Argentine statesman and priest (d. approx. 1820)

heading: Births
txt: Richard Mentor Johnson, American politician, ninth Vice President of the United States (d. 1850)

entities.title: Richard Mentor Johnson
entities.description: Richard Mentor Johnson was an American lawyer and politician who served as the ninth vice president of the United States, serving from 1837 to 1841 under President Martin Van Buren. He is the only vice president elected by the United States Senate under the provisions of the Twelfth Amendment. Johnson also represented Kentucky in the U.S. House of Representatives and Senate. He began and ended his

heading: Births
txt: Johann Friedrich Meckel, German anatomist (d. 1833)

entities.title: Johann Friedrich Meckel
entities.description: Johann Friedrich Meckel, often referred to as Johann Friedrich Meckel, the Younger, was a German anatomist born in Halle. He worked as a professor of anatomy, pathology and zoology at the University of Halle, Germany.

heading: Births
txt: Fructuoso Rivera, first president of Uruguay (d. 1854)

entities.title: Fructuoso Rivera
entities.description: José Fructuoso Rivera y Toscana was a Uruguayan general and patriot who fought for the liberation of Banda Oriental from Brazilian rule, twice served as Uruguay's President and was one of the instigators of the long Uruguayan Civil War. He is also considered to be the founder of the Colorado Party, which ruled Uruguay without interruption from 1865 until 1958. He made a controversial decision to a

entities.title: Uruguay
entities.description: Uruguay, officially the Oriental Republic of Uruguay, is a country in South America. It shares borders with Argentina to its west and southwest and Brazil to its north and northeast; while bordering the Río de la Plata to the south and the Atlantic Ocean to the southeast. Uruguay has a population of an estimated 3.51 million, of whom 2 million live in the metropolitan area of its capital and large

heading: Births
txt: Christen Smith, Norwegian scientist (d. 1816)

entities.title: Christen Smith
entities.description: Christen Smith was an early 19th-century Norwegian physician, economist and naturalist, particularly botanist. He died, only 30 years old during a dramatic expedition to the Congo River in 1816, leaving a wealth of botanical material.

heading: Births
txt: John Bowring, English polyglot and governor of Hong Kong (d. 1826)

entities.title: John Bowring
entities.description: Sir John Bowring was an English political economist, traveller, writer, literary translator, polyglot and the fourth Governor of Hong Kong.

entities.title: Polyglotism
entities.description: Multilingualism is the use of more than one language, either by an individual speaker or by a group of speakers. It is believed that multilingual speakers outnumber monolingual speakers in the world's population. More than half of all Europeans claim to speak at least one language other than their mother tongue; but many read and write in one language. Always useful to traders, multilingualism is

entities.title: Governor of Hong Kong
entities.description: The Governor of Hong Kong was the representative of the British Crown in Hong Kong from 1843 to 1997. In this capacity, the governor was president of the Executive Council and Commander-in-Chief of the British Forces Overseas Hong Kong. The governor's roles were defined in the Hong Kong Letters Patent and Royal Instructions. Upon the end of British rule and the handover of Hong Kong to China in 19

heading: Births
txt: Juan Lavalle, Argentine politician (d.1841)

entities.title: Juan Lavalle
entities.description: Juan Galo Lavalle was an Argentine military and political figure.

heading: Births
txt: Ferenc Deák, Hungarian politician (d. 1876)

entities.title: Ferenc Deák
entities.description: Ferenc Deák de Kehida was a Hungarian statesman and Minister of Justice. He was known as "The Wise Man of the Nation" and one of the greatest figures of Hungary's liberal movement.

heading: Births
txt: Adolphe-Félix Cals, French painter (d. 1880)

entities.title: Adolphe-Félix Cals
entities.description: Adolphe-Félix Cals was a French portrait, genre, and landscape painter.

heading: Births
txt: Albertus van Raalte, Dutch-American pastor and educator (d. 1876)

entities.title: Albertus van Raalte
entities.description: Albertus Christiaan van Raalte was a 19th-century Dutch Reformed clergyman. Van Raalte was first ordained in the Secession Church in 1836, before moving to the United States, and was eventually ordained in the Reformed Church in America. When he visited the lower peninsula of Michigan, he met with Grand Haven founder William Montague Ferry. Ferry encouraged Van Raalte to settle in the Holland area

heading: Births
txt: Georg Büchner, German-Swiss poet and playwright (d. 1837)

entities.title: Georg Büchner
entities.description: Karl Georg Büchner was a German dramatist and writer of poetry and prose, considered part of the Young Germany movement. He was also a revolutionary and the brother of physician and philosopher Ludwig Büchner. His literary achievements, though few in number, are generally held in great esteem in Germany and it is widely believed that, had it not been for his early death, he might have joined such

heading: Births
txt: Yakiv Holovatsky, Ukrainian historian, scholar, and poet (d. 1888)

entities.title: Yakiv Holovatsky
entities.description: Yakub, Yakov, Yakiv Holovatsky, also Yakov Golovatsky was a noted Galician historian, literary scholar, ethnographer, linguist, bibliographer, lexicographer, poet and leader of Galician Russophiles. He was a member of the Ruthenian Triad, one of the most influential Ukrainian literary groups in the Austrian Empire.

heading: Births
txt: Syed Ahmad Khan, Indian philosopher and scholar (d. 1898)

entities.title: Syed Ahmad Khan
entities.description: Sir Syed Ahmad Taqvi bin Syed Muhammad Muttaqi KCSI, commonly known as Sir Syed Ahmad Khan, was an Islamic pragmatist, Islamic reformer, philosopher, and educationist in nineteenth-century British India. Though initially espousing Hindu-Muslim unity, he became the pioneer of Muslim nationalism in India and is widely credited as the father of Two-Nation Theory which formed the basis of Pakistan mov

heading: Births
txt: Alexander Gardner, Scottish photographer (d. 1882)

entities.title: Alexander Gardner (photographer)
entities.description: Alexander Gardner was a Scottish photographer who immigrated to the United States in 1856, where he began to work full-time in that profession. He is best known for his photographs of the American Civil War, U.S. President Abraham Lincoln, and the execution of the conspirators to Lincoln's assassination.

heading: Births
txt: Aureliano Maestre de San Juan, Spanish scientist (d. 1890)

entities.title: Aureliano Maestre de San Juan
entities.description: Aureliano Maestre de San Juan was a Spanish scientist, histologist, physician and anatomist. He is credited as being one of the first scientists to recognize the disorder known as Kallmann syndrome. He died in 1890, having been blinded in a laboratory accident involving caustic soda two years earlier.

heading: Births
txt: José E. Días, Paraguayan general (d. 1867)

entities.title: José E. Díaz
entities.description: José Eduvigis Díaz Vera was a celebrated Paraguayan general. Díaz was born in the town of Cerro Verá east of Pirayú in the department of Paraguarí. His parents were named Juan Andrés Díaz and Dolores Vera.

heading: Births
txt: Louis-Léon Cugnot, French sculptor (d. 1894)

entities.title: Louis-Léon Cugnot
entities.description: Louis-Léon Cugnot was a French sculptor.

heading: Births
txt: Paul Haenlein, German mechanical engineer (d.1905)

heading: Births
txt: André Gill, French caricaturist (d. 1885)

entities.title: André Gill
entities.description: André Gill was a French caricaturist. Born Louis-Alexandre Gosset de Guînes at Paris, the son of the Comte de Guînes and Sylvie-Adeline Gosset. Gill studied at the Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture. He adopted the pseudonym André Gill in homage to his hero, James Gillray. Gill began illustrating for Le Journal Amusant. Gill, however, became known for his work for the weekly four-sheet newspa

entities.title: Caricaturist
entities.description: A caricaturist is an artist who specializes in drawing caricatures.

heading: Births
txt: Gustave Schlumberger, French historian (d. 1929)

entities.title: Gustave Schlumberger
entities.description: Léon Gustave Schlumberger was a French historian and numismatist who specialised in the era of the crusades and the Byzantine Empire. His Numismatique de l'Orient Latin (1878–82) is still considered the principal work on the coinage of the crusades. He was awarded the medal of the Royal Numismatic Society in 1903. A large portion of his extensive Crusader coin collection is housed in the Cabinet d

heading: Births
txt: John J. Gardner, American politician (d. 1921)

entities.title: John J. Gardner
entities.description: John James Gardner was an American Republican Party politician who represented New Jersey's 2nd congressional district in the United States House of Representatives for five terms from 1893 to 1913, and was Mayor of Atlantic City, New Jersey.

heading: Births
txt: Grand Duchess Maria Alexandrovna of Russia (d. 1920)

entities.title: Grand Duchess Maria Alexandrovna of Russia
entities.description: Grand Duchess Maria Alexandrovna of Russia, later Duchess of Edinburgh and Duchess of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, was the fifth child and only surviving daughter of Emperor Alexander II of Russia and his first wife, Princess Marie of Hesse and by Rhine. She was the younger sister of Alexander III of Russia and the paternal aunt of Russia's last emperor, Nicholas II.

heading: Births
txt: Childe Hassam, American painter and illustrator (d. 1935)

entities.title: Childe Hassam
entities.description: Frederick Childe Hassam was an American Impressionist painter, noted for his urban and coastal scenes. Along with Mary Cassatt and John Henry Twachtman, Hassam was instrumental in promulgating Impressionism to American collectors, dealers, and museums. He produced over 3,000 paintings, oils, watercolors, etchings, and lithographs over the course of his career, and was an influential American artis

heading: Births
txt: Henry Campbell Black, founder of Black's Law Dictionary (d. 1927)

entities.title: Henry Campbell Black
entities.description: Henry Campbell Black was the founder of Black's Law Dictionary, the definitive legal dictionary first published in 1891.

heading: Births
txt: Elinor Glyn, English author, screenwriter, and producer (d. 1943)

entities.title: Elinor Glyn
entities.description: Elinor Glyn was a British novelist and scriptwriter who specialised in romantic fiction, which was considered scandalous for its time, although her works are relatively tame by modern standards. She popularized the concept of the It-girl, and had tremendous influence on early 20th-century popular culture and, possibly, on the careers of notable Hollywood stars such as Rudolph Valentino, Gloria Swa

heading: Births
txt: James Rudolph Garfield, American lawyer and politician, 23rd United States Secretary of the Interior (d. 1950)

entities.title: James Rudolph Garfield
entities.description: James Rudolph Garfield was an American politician and lawyer. Garfield was a son of President James A. Garfield and First Lady Lucretia Garfield. He served as Secretary of the Interior during President Theodore Roosevelt's administration.

entities.title: United States Secretary of the Interior
entities.description: The United States secretary of the interior is the head of the United States Department of the Interior. The secretary and the Department of the Interior are responsible for the management and conservation of most federal land and natural resources, leading such agencies as the Bureau of Land Management, the United States Geological Survey, Bureau of Indian Affairs, and the National Park Service.

heading: Births
txt: Josep Puig i Cadafalch, Catalan architect who designed the Casa Martí (d. 1956)

entities.title: Josep Puig i Cadafalch
entities.description: Josep Puig i Cadafalch was a Catalan Spanish Modernista architect who designed many significant buildings in Barcelona, and a politician who had a significant role in the development of Catalan institutions. He was the architect of the Casa Martí, which became a place of ideas, projects and social gatherings for such well-known Catalans as Santiago Rusiñol and Ramon Casas.

entities.title: Catalonia
entities.description: Catalonia is an autonomous community in the northeastern corner of Spain, designated as a nationality by its Statute of Autonomy.

entities.title: Casa Martí
entities.description: The Casa Martí is a modernista building designed by Josep Puig i Cadafalch in 1896, having been commissioned by relatives of Francesc Vilumara, a textile magnate. It stands at Carrer Montsió, 3, Barcelona.

heading: Births
txt: Segundo de Chomón, Spanish cinematographer, director, and screenwriter (d.1929)

entities.title: Segundo de Chomón
entities.description: Segundo Víctor Aurelio Chomón y Ruiz was a pioneering Spanish film director, cinematographer and screenwriter. He produced many short films in France while working for Pathé Frères and has been compared to Georges Méliès, due to his frequent camera tricks and optical illusions. He is regarded as the most significant Spanish silent film director in an international context.

entities.title: Cinematographer
entities.description: A cinematographer or director of photography is the chief over the camera and light crews working on a film, television production or other live action piece and is responsible for making artistic and technical decisions related to the image. The study and practice of this field is referred to as cinematography.

heading: Births
txt: Hippolyte Aucouturier, French cyclist (d. 1944)

entities.title: Hippolyte Aucouturier
entities.description: Hippolyte Aucouturier was a French professional road bicycle racer. Aucouturier, a professional between 1900 and 1908, won two stages at the first Tour de France in 1903 and won three stages and finished second in the 1905 Tour de France. He also won Paris–Roubaix twice, in 1903 and 1904. His elder brother Francois was also a racing cyclist.

entities.title: Cycling
entities.description: Cycling, also called bicycling or biking, is the use of bicycles for transport, recreation, exercise or sport. People engaged in cycling are referred to as "cyclists", "bicyclists", or "bikers". Apart from two-wheeled bicycles, "cycling" also includes the riding of unicycles, tricycles, quadricycles, recumbent and similar human-powered vehicles (HPVs).

heading: Births
txt: Jacobo Fitz-James Stuart, Spanish politician and 17th Duke of Alba (d. 1953)

entities.title: Jacobo Fitz-James Stuart, 17th Duke of Alba
entities.description: Jacobo Fitz-James Stuart y Falcó, 17th Duke of Alba, 10th Duke of Berwick, GE was a Spanish peer, diplomat, politician, art collector, and olympic medalist. A Jacobite, he was the most senior surviving male-line descendant of James II and, despite having never made a claim, he was considered by some as the legitimate heir to the throne of Scotland. He was one of the most important aristocrats of h

entities.title: Duke of Alba
entities.description: Duke of Alba de Tormes, commonly known as Duke of Alba, is a title of Spanish nobility that is accompanied by the dignity of Grandee of Spain. In 1472, the title of Count of Alba de Tormes, inherited by García Álvarez de Toledo, was elevated to the title of Duke of Alba de Tormes by King Henry IV of Castile.

heading: Births
txt: Jesús Reyes Ferreira, Mexican artist and art collector (d. 1977)

entities.title: Jesús Reyes Ferreira
entities.description: Jesús Reyes Ferreira, (1880-1977) born José de Jesús Benjamín Buenaventura de los Reyes y Ferreira and also known as Chucho Reyes, was a self-taught artist and antiques/art collector and vendor. Reyes Ferreira began painting on crêpe paper, a delicate material not meant to last, as a way of decorating paper meant to wrap sales from his antiques/art store. The decorated paper became popular enough

heading: Births
txt: Maria Dulęba, Polish actress (d. 1959)

entities.title: Maria Dulęba
entities.description: Maria Zofia Dulęba was a Polish stage and film actress. She made her stage debut in 1902 and went on to perform in a number of films, mostly in the silent era. She later also taught drama.

heading: Births
txt: Haritina Korotkevich, Russian war heroine (d. 1904)

entities.title: Haritina Korotkevich
entities.description: Haritina Evstafievna Korotkevich was a soldier who served in the Imperial Russian Army during the Russo-Japanese War. Volunteering to serve disguised as a man under the pseudonym Khariton Korotkevich, she soon gained a reputation as a fearless leader as a woman in her own right. She was killed by shellfire on the front line during the Siege of Port Arthur.

heading: Births
txt: Alexander Neill, Scottish educator (d. 1973)

entities.title: Alexander Neill
entities.description: Alexander Sutherland Neill was a Scottish educator and author known for his school, Summerhill, and its philosophy of freedom from adult coercion and community self-governance. Raised in Scotland, Neill taught at several schools before attending the University of Edinburgh in 1908–1912. He took two jobs in journalism before World War I, and taught at Gretna Green Village School in the first year o

heading: Births
txt: Thaddeus Shideler, American hurdler (d. 1966)

entities.title: Hurdler
entities.description: Hurdling is the act of jumping over an obstacle at a high speed or in a sprint. In the early 19th century, hurdlers ran at and jumped over each hurdle, landing on both feet and checking their forward motion. Today, the dominant step patterns are the 3-step for high hurdles, 7-step for low hurdles, and 15-step for intermediate hurdles. Hurdling is a highly specialized form of obstacle racing, and i

heading: Births
txt: Spring Byington, American actress (d. 1971)

entities.title: Spring Byington
entities.description: Spring Dell Byington was an American actress. Her career included a seven-year run on radio and television as the star of December Bride. She was a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer contract player who appeared in films from the 1930s to the 1960s. Byington received a nomination for an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for her role as Penelope Sycamore in You Can't Take It with You (1938).

heading: Births
txt: Mikha'il Na'ima, Lebanese author (d. 1988)

entities.title: Mikha'il Na'ima
entities.description: Mikha'il Nu'ayma, better known in English by his pen name Mikhail Naimy, was a Lebanese Greek Orthodox poet, novelist, and philosopher, famous for his spiritual writings, notably The Book of Mirdad. He is widely recognized as one of the most important figures in modern Arabic literature and one of the most important spiritual writers of the 20th century.

entities.title: Lebanon
entities.description: Lebanon, officially known as the Lebanese Republic, is a country in Western Asia. It is bordered by Syria to the north and east and Israel to the south, while Cyprus lies west across the Mediterranean Sea. Lebanon's location at the crossroads of the Mediterranean Basin and the Arabian hinterland has contributed to its rich history and shaped a cultural identity of religious and ethnic diversity. A

heading: Births
txt: Roy Kilner, English cricketer (d. 1928)

entities.title: Roy Kilner
entities.description: Roy Kilner was an English professional cricketer who played nine Test matches for England between 1924 and 1926. An all-rounder, he played for Yorkshire County Cricket Club between 1911 and 1927. In all first-class matches, he scored 14,707 runs at an average of 30.01 and took 1,003 wickets at an average of 18.45. Kilner scored 1,000 runs in a season ten times and took 100 wickets in a season five

heading: Births
txt: Theodor Eicke, German SS general (d. 1943)

entities.title: Theodor Eicke
entities.description: Theodor Eicke was a German SS functionary during the Nazi era. He was one of the key figures in the development of Nazi concentration camps during the Holocaust.

heading: Births
txt: Herbert Howells, English organist, composer, and educator (d. 1983)

heading: Births
txt: Raffaele Bendandi, Italian clockmaker and seismologist (d. 1979)

entities.title: Raffaele Bendandi
entities.description: Raffaele Bendandi was an Italian clockmaker known for his predictions of earthquakes. Bendandi was self-taught and never published a verifiable scientific exposition of his theory.

heading: Births
txt: Prince René, Italian Prince of Denmark (d. 1962)

entities.title: Prince René of Bourbon-Parma
entities.description: Prince René of Bourbon-Parma was the seventh surviving son of Robert I, Duke of Parma, and his second wife, Infanta Maria Antonia of Portugal. In 1921, he married Princess Margaret of Denmark. They had four children including Queen Anne of Romania, the wife of Michael I, former King of Romania.

entities.title: Denmark
entities.description: Denmark, officially the Kingdom of Denmark, is a Nordic country in Northern Europe. Denmark proper, which is the southernmost of the Scandinavian countries, consists of a peninsula, Jutland, and an archipelago of 443 named islands, with the largest being Zealand, Funen and the North Jutlandic Island. The islands are characterised by flat, arable land and sandy coasts, low elevation and a temperate

heading: Births
txt: Pablo de Rokha, Chilean poet (d. 1968)

heading: Births
txt: Miguel Ydígoras Fuentes, President of Guatemala (1958–1963) (d. 1982)

entities.title: Miguel Ydígoras Fuentes
entities.description: General José Miguel Ramón Ydígoras Fuentes was the conservative President of Guatemala from 1958 to March 1963. He was also the main challenger to Jacobo Árbenz during the 1950 presidential election. He had previously served as the governor of the province of San Marcos.

entities.title: President of Guatemala
entities.description: The President of Guatemala, officially known as the President of the Republic of Guatemala, is the head of state and head of government of Guatemala, elected to a single four-year term. The position of President was created in 1839.

heading: Births
txt: Doris Humphrey, American dancer and choreographer (d. 1958)

heading: Births
txt: Roman Petrovich, Russian prince (d. 1978)

entities.title: Prince Roman Petrovich of Russia
entities.description: Prince Roman Petrovich of Russia was a member of the House of Romanov.

heading: Births
txt: Shinichi Suzuki, Japanese violinist and educator (d. 1998)

entities.title: Shinichi Suzuki (violinist)
entities.description: Shinichi Suzuki  was a Japanese musician, philosopher, and educator and the founder of the international Suzuki method of music education and developed a philosophy for educating people of all ages and abilities. Considered an influential pedagogue in music education of children, he often spoke of the ability of all children to learn things well, especially in the right environment, and of develop

heading: Births
txt: Eileen Sedgwick, American actress (d. 1991)

heading: Births
txt: Simon Vestdijk, Dutch author and poet (d. 1971)

heading: Births
txt: C. C. van Asch van Wijck, Dutch artist and sculptor (d. 1932)

entities.title: C. C. van Asch van Wijck
entities.description: Jonkvrouwe (Lady) Cornélie Caroline "Cox" van Asch van Wijck was a Dutch artist and sculptor.

heading: Births
txt: Jean Arthur, American actress (d. 1991)

heading: Births
txt: Yvor Winters, American critic and poet (d. 1968)

heading: Births
txt: Emma Gamboa Alvarado, Costa Rican educator (d. 1973)

entities.title: Emma Gamboa Alvarado
entities.description: Emma Gamboa Alvarado, was a Costa Rican educator, recognized for her contributions to pedagogy and teaching. She was declared Benemérita de la Patria by the Legislative Assembly of Costa Rica in 1980. She was depicted on the ten thousand colones bill of 1998.

heading: Births
txt: Irene Ryan, American actress (d. 1973)

entities.title: Irene Ryan

entities.title: Agrippina the Elder
entities.description: Vipsania Agrippina, commonly referred to as Agrippina the Elder, was a prominent member of the Julio-Claudian dynasty. At the time of her birth, her brothers Lucius and Gaius were the adoptive sons of Augustus and were his heirs until their

entities.title: Germanicus
entities.description: Germanicus Julius Caesar was a popular and prominent general of the Roman Empire, known for his campaigns in Germania. The son of Nero Claudius Drusus and Antonia the Younger, Germanicus was born into an influential branch of the patrician gens Claudia. heading: Deaths
txt: Al-Musta'in, Abbasid caliph (b. 836)

entities.title: Al-Musta'in
entities.description: Al-Musta'in was the Abbasid Caliph from 862 to 866, during the "Anarchy at Samarra". After the death of previous Caliph, al-Muntasir, the Turkic military leaders held a council to select his successor. They were not willing to have al-Mu'tazz or his brothers; so they elected Ahmad ibn Muhammad أحمد بن محمد, a grandson of al-Mu'tasim, who took the regnal name al-Mustaʿin bi-llah.

She was 15 years old when she married the 60-year-old English prince, who proved to be a very devoted husband. In spite of the difference in their ages, Beatrice survived him by only five years, dying in England aged 23.

entities.description: The post of Lord High Treasurer or Lord Treasurer was an English government position and has been a British government position since the Acts of Union of 1707. A holder of the post would be the third-highest-ranked Great Officer of State, below the Lord High Steward and the Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain.

heading: Deaths
txt: Margaret Mary Alacoque, French mystic (b. 1647)

entities.title: Margaret Mary Alacoque
entities.description: Margaret Mary Alacoque, was a French Roman Catholic Visitation nun and mystic, who promoted devotion to the Sacred Heart of Jesus in its modern form.

heading: Deaths
txt: René Antoine Ferchault de Réaumur, French entomologist and academic (b. 1683)

entities.title: René Antoine Ferchault de Réaumur
entities.description: René Antoine Ferchault de Réaumur was a French entomologist and writer who contributed to many different fields, especially the study of insects. He introduced the Réaumur temperature scale.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pierre François le Courayer, French-English theologian and author (b. 1681)

entities.title: Pierre François le Courayer
entities.description: Pierre François le Courayer was a French Catholic theological writer, for many years an expatriate in England.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Cookworthy, English pharmacist and minister (b. 1705)

entities.title: William Cookworthy
entities.description: William Cookworthy was an English Quaker minister, a successful pharmacist and an innovator in several fields of technology. He was the first person in Britain to discover how to make hard-paste porcelain, like that imported from China. He subsequently discovered china clay in Cornwall. In 1768 he founded a works at Plymouth for the production of Plymouth porcelain; in 1770 he moved the factory to

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward Hawke, 1st Baron Hawke, English admiral (b. 1705)

entities.title: Edward Hawke, 1st Baron Hawke
entities.description: Admiral of the Fleet Edward Hawke, 1st Baron Hawke, KB, PC, of Scarthingwell Hall in the parish of Towton, near Tadcaster, Yorkshire, was a Royal Navy officer. As captain of the third-rate HMS Berwick, he took part in the Battle of Toulon in February 1744 during the War of the Austrian Succession. He also captured six ships of a French squadron in the Bay of Biscay in the Second Battle of Cape Fin

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Ludwig Aberli, Swiss painter and illustrator (b. 1723)

entities.title: Johann Ludwig Aberli
entities.description: Johann Ludwig Aberli was a Swiss painter and etcher.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Jacques Dessalines, Haitian commander and politician, Governor-General of Haiti (b. 1758)

entities.title: Jean-Jacques Dessalines
entities.description: Jean-Jacques Dessalines was a leader of the Haitian Revolution and the first ruler of an independent Haiti under the 1805 constitution. Under Dessalines, Haiti became the first country to permanently abolish slavery. Initially regarded as governor-general, Dessalines was later named Emperor of Haiti as Jacques I (1804–1806) by generals of the Haitian Revolution Army and ruled in that capacity unti

entities.title: List of heads of state of Haiti
entities.description: This article lists the heads of state of Haiti since the beginning of the Haitian Revolution in 1791. Full independence of Haiti was declared in 1804.

heading: Deaths
txt: Orest Kiprensky, Russian painter (b. 1782)

entities.title: Orest Kiprensky
entities.description: Orest Adamovich Kiprensky was a leading Russian portraitist in the Age of Romanticism. His most familiar work is probably his portrait of Alexander Pushkin (1827), which prompted the poet to remark that "the mirror flatters me".

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Nepomuk Hummel, Austrian pianist and composer (b. 1778)

entities.title: Johann Nepomuk Hummel
entities.description: Johann Nepomuk Hummel was an Austrian composer and virtuoso pianist. His music reflects the transition from the classical to the romantic musical era.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frédéric Chopin, Polish pianist and composer (b. 1810)

entities.title: Frédéric Chopin
entities.description: Frédéric François Chopin, born Fryderyk Franciszek Chopin, was a Polish composer and virtuoso pianist of the Romantic period who wrote primarily for solo piano. He has maintained worldwide renown as a leading musician of his era, one whose "poetic genius was based on a professional technique that was without equal in his generation."

heading: Deaths
txt: Laura Secord, Canadian war heroine (b. 1775)

entities.title: Laura Secord
entities.description: Laura Secord was a Canadian heroine of the War of 1812. She is known for having walked 20 miles (32 km) out of American-occupied territory in 1813 to warn British forces of an impending American attack. Her contribution to the war was little known during her lifetime, but since her death she has been frequently honoured in Canada. Though Laura Secord had no relation to it, most Canadians associate

entities.title: War of 1812
entities.description: The War of 1812 was a conflict fought between the United States and its allies, and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and its dependent colonies in North America and Indian allies. The conflict began when the United States declared war in June 1812, and ended in a restoration of the pre-war status quo when a peace treaty agreed to earlier was ratified by the United States in February

heading: Deaths
txt: Gustav Kirchhoff, German physicist and chemist (b. 1824)

entities.title: Gustav Kirchhoff
entities.description: Gustav Robert Kirchhoff was a German physicist who contributed to the fundamental understanding of electrical circuits, spectroscopy, and the emission of black-body radiation by heated objects.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nikolay Chernyshevsky, Russian philosopher and critic (b. 1828)

entities.title: Nikolay Chernyshevsky
entities.description: Nikolay Gavrilovich Chernyshevsky 	(24 July [O.S. 12 July] 1828 – 17 October 1889) was a Russian literary and social critic, journalist, novelist, democrat, and socialist philosopher, often identified as a utopian socialist and leading theoretician of Russian nihilism. He was the dominant intellectual figure of the 1860s revolutionary democratic movement in Russia, despite spending much of his lat

heading: Deaths
txt: Patrice de MacMahon, Duke of Magenta, French general and politician, 3rd President of France (b. 1808)

entities.title: Patrice de MacMahon, Duke of Magenta
entities.description: Patrice de MacMahon, marquis de MacMahon, duc de Magenta, was a French general and politician, with the distinction of Marshal of France. He served as Chief of State of France from 1873 to 1875 and as President of France, from 1875 to 1879.

entities.title: President of France
entities.description: The president of France, officially the president of the French Republic, is the head of state and head of executive of France as well as the commander-in-chief of the French Armed Forces. The French presidency is the supreme magistracy of the country, and the president is the holder of the highest office in France.

heading: Deaths
txt: Julia Ward Howe, American poet and songwriter (b. 1819)

entities.title: Julia Ward Howe
entities.description: Julia Ward Howe was an American poet and author, known for writing "The Battle Hymn of the Republic" and the original 1870 pacifist Mother's Day Proclamation. She was also an advocate for abolitionism and a social activist, particularly for women's suffrage.

heading: Deaths
txt: Malak Hifni Nasif, Egyptian poet and author (b. 1886)

entities.title: Malak Hifni Nasif
entities.description: Malak Hifni Nasif was an Egyptian feminist who contributed greatly to the intellectual and political discourse on the advancement of Egyptian women in the early 20th century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Michael Fitzgerald (Irish republican) died on Hunger Strike (b. 1881)

entities.title: Michael Fitzgerald (Irish republican)
entities.description: Michael Fitzgerald also known as Mick Fitzgerald, was among the first members of the Irish Republican Army and played an important role in organizing it. He rose to the rank of Commandant OC in the First Battalion, Cork Number 2 Brigade. He died in the 1920 hunger strike at Cork Gaol. His death is credited with bringing world-wide attention to the Irish cause for independence.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frank Dicksee, English painter and illustrator (b. 1853)

entities.title: Frank Dicksee
entities.description: Sir Francis Bernard Dicksee was an English Victorian painter and illustrator, best known for his pictures of dramatic literary, historical, and legendary scenes. He also was a noted painter of portraits of fashionable women, which helped to bring him success in his own time.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfons Maria Jakob, German neurologist and academic (b. 1884)

entities.title: Alfons Maria Jakob
entities.description: Alfons Maria Jakob was a German neurologist who worked in the field of neuropathology.

heading: Deaths
txt: J. Bruce Ismay, English businessman (b. 1862)

entities.title: J. Bruce Ismay
entities.description: Joseph Bruce Ismay was an English businessman who served as chairman and managing director of the White Star Line. In 1912, he came to international attention as the highest-ranking White Star official to survive the sinking of the company's new flagship RMS Titanic, for which he was subject to severe criticism.

heading: Deaths
txt: Karl Kautsky, Czech-German journalist, philosopher, and theoretician (b. 1854)

entities.title: Karl Kautsky
entities.description: Karl Johann Kautsky was a Czech-Austrian philosopher, journalist, and Marxist theoretician. Kautsky was one of the most authoritative promulgators of orthodox Marxism after the death of Friedrich Engels in 1895 until the outbreak of World War I in 1914. He was the most important socialist theorist during the years of the Second International. He founded the socialist journal Neue Zeit.

heading: Deaths
txt: Royal Cortissoz, American art critic (b. 1869)

entities.title: Royal Cortissoz
entities.description: Royal Cortissoz was an American art historian and from 1891 until his death, the art critic for the New York Herald Tribune. During his tenure at the newspaper, he consistently championed traditionalism and decried modernism. Of the latter, he once wrote, "It will someday prove a kind of Victorian 'dud,' with a difference, obviously, but a 'dud' just the same."

heading: Deaths
txt: Dimitrios Maximos, Greek banker and politician (b. 1873)

entities.title: Dimitrios Maximos
entities.description: Dimitrios E. Maximos was a Greek banker and politician. He briefly served as Prime Minister of Greece after World War II.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anne Crawford, Israeli-English actress (b. 1920)

entities.title: Anne Crawford
entities.description: Imelda Anne Crawford was a British film actress, born in Palestine of an English mother and Scottish father and brought up in Edinburgh.

heading: Deaths
txt: Wilhelmina Hay Abbott, Scottish suffragist and feminist (b. 1884)

entities.title: Wilhelmina Hay Abbott
entities.description: Wilhelmina Hay Abbott, also known by the name "Elizabeth Abbott," was a Scottish suffragist, editor, and feminist lecturer, and wife of author George Frederick Abbott.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Outerbridge, American photographer (b. 1896)

entities.title: Paul Outerbridge
entities.description: Paul Outerbridge, Jr. was an American photographer prominent for his early use and experiments in color photography.

entities.title: Natalia Goncharova
entities.description: Natalia Sergeevna Goncharova was a Russian avant-garde artist, painter, costume designer, writer, illustrator, and set designer. Goncharova's lifelong partner was fellow Russian avant-garde artist Mikhail Larionov. She was a founding member of both the Jack of Diamonds (1909–1911), Moscow's first radical independent exhibiting group, the more radical Donkey's Tail (1912–1913), and with Larionov in

heading: Deaths
txt: Jacques Hadamard, French mathematician and academic (b. 1865)

entities.title: Jacques Hadamard
entities.description: Jacques Salomon Hadamard ForMemRS was a French mathematician who made major contributions in number theory, complex analysis, differential geometry and partial differential equations.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bart King, American cricketer (b. 1873)

entities.title: Bart King
entities.description: John Barton "Bart" King was an American cricketer, active in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. King was part of the Philadelphia team that played from the end of the 19th century until the outbreak of World War I. This period of cricket in the United States was dominated by "gentlemen cricketers"—men of independent wealth who did not need to work. King, an amateur from a middle-class family,

heading: Deaths
txt: Sidney Hatch, American runner and soldier (b. 1883)

entities.title: Sidney Hatch
entities.description: Sidney Hatch was an American athlete who competed for the United States in the 1904 Summer Olympics held in St. Louis, United States, in the 4 mile team where he won the silver medal with his teammates James Lightbody, Frank Verner, Lacey Hearn and Frenchman Albert Corey.

heading: Deaths
txt: Wieland Wagner, German director and manager (b. 1917)

heading: Deaths
txt: Puyi, Chinese emperor (b. 1906)

entities.title: Puyi
entities.description: Puyi was the last Emperor of China as the eleventh and final Qing dynasty ruler. Becoming the Xuantong Emperor at age two but forced to abdicate on 12 February 1912 due to the Xinhai Revolution, he later served as the nominal ruler of the Japanese puppet state of Manchukuo during World War II.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pierre Laporte, Canadian journalist, lawyer, and politician (b. 1921)

entities.title: Pierre Laporte
entities.description: Pierre Laporte was a Canadian lawyer, journalist and politician. He was deputy premier of the province of Quebec when he was kidnapped by members of the Front de libération du Québec (FLQ) during the October Crisis. When the FLQ's demands were refused, they killed him. Laporte's body was found in the trunk of Paul Rose's car.

entities.description: Walter Edward Broda was a Canadian professional ice hockey player and coach. A goaltender, Broda played his entire career for the Toronto Maple Leafs of the National Hockey League (NHL) between 1935 and 1951, taking a brief hiatus from 1943 to 1946 to fight in the Second World War. After retiring from active play, Broda coached minor league and junior ice hockey teams. In 2017 Broda was named one

entities.title: Ingeborg Bachmann
